stocks.note: *Numbers as of market close on Feb 9th
stocks.news:
Novo Nordisk (NVO +3.63%), the company behind Ozempic, is suing Hims and Hers (+1.03%).

Why? Novo says Hims was illegally offering a copycat version of the weight-loss drug.

Hims pulled its weight-loss drugs at the end of last week after the FDA said it would investigate Hims.

Deal Of The Century

Alphabet (GOOG +0.40%), the parent company of Google, says it's selling $15B worth of bonds.

The bonds will be issued in USD, with additional bond sales in Swiss francs and even 100-year bonds in pounds sterling.

‚Ä¢ AI is creating opportunities for high-grade corporate debt sales.

economy.commentary:
The Dollar Drop

The U.S. dollar just hit its lowest point in more than four years.

What does that mean? Basically, other currencies are rising against the dollar.

Some investors say the dollar has been weak because of economic uncertainty from policies like tariffs.

crypto.note: *Numbers as of 4:40 pm ET on Feb 9th
crypto.commentary:
Companies that load up on crypto have taken a big hit in the last month, with Strategy (MSTR +2.60%) and Bitmine (BMNR +4.89%) each down more than 10%.

Refresher: Strategy's business model is to buy a bunch of Bitcoin, and Bitmine is doing the same but with Ethereum.

Bitmine's Tom Lee said the company is still buying the dip on Ethereum - even as the company sits on a big paper loss.

real_estate.homebuilder:
Slow Grow:

Home prices are rising more slowly as of December 2025 according to a new report.

A year-over-year growth rate of 0.9% is the lowest over 15 years.

Cities in U.S. Southern and Western states like Texas, Florida, and Hawaii are seeing actual dropping prices.
real_estate.commentary:
üèóÔ∏è Alameda County News:

The "stabilization" trend is the main theme for Alameda County today.

‚Ä¢ Price Divergence: Single-family homes are holding steady with a median price of roughly $968,000, while the condo market is struggling, seeing year-over-year declines in the double digits in some areas.

‚Ä¢ Sales Activity: Interestingly, over the weekend and through yesterday (Feb 9), several homes in cities like Dublin and Oakland sold for 30% to 45% over asking, signaling that the "bidding war" culture isn't dead for move-in-ready properties.

üìç Fremont Spotlight

Fremont continues to be one of the most resilient "micro-markets" in the East Bay.

‚Ä¢ Market Action Index: As of this week, Fremont holds a score of 67, categorizing it as a Strong Seller's Market. While this is a slight dip from last month's 69, it remains significantly higher than the national average.

‚Ä¢ Pricing: The median list price is presently hovering around $1,649,444.

‚Ä¢ Inventory: There is a slight uptick in choices for buyers, with 56 active listings this week. However, the median days on market is a crisp 18 days, meaning well-priced homes are still moving in under three weeks.

üóùÔ∏è Key Takeaway for Today:

If you are looking in Fremont, the "hot" homes are still going pending in under 10 days. In Milpitas, the market is slightly more forgiving for buyers (34 days on average), but the lack of new listings means you have to act immediately when a property hits the MLS.
